title: Producto excelente
text: El empaquetado sin problemas toca probar el comportamiento
author: Amazon Customer

title: The Best VR Headset Out There
text:
I have owned a lot of VR Headsets out there... Original Oculus Rift, Samsung HMD Odyssey+ Windows Mixed Reality, HTC Vibe, Quest 2, etc.. . By far, Oculus has the best over balance of price, performance, features, and applications. If you are new to VR, this is the right product for you. If you are a Quest 2 owner (I have one) and have some extra cash to upgrade, this is also the right product for you. If you don't have the cash or just want to see what Quest 4 is all about when it shows up (I presume there will be a Quest 4 coming out in the far future), your Quest 2 will keep you going OK. For me the stuff that I like about the Quest 3 over the Quest 2 (and other products) is:
- Pass through video. This is where the future is going. I think we are just seeing developers scratch the surface for what you can do this. I expect more "AR" like applications and games in the future. Right now, the available applications and games are few and simple, but I expect more in the future. I also like not taking off my Headset to do simple stuff like check my phone, grab my drink, check to make sure the kids aren't setting the house on fire, etc.. you get the point. Could Meta have done better with pass through? Yep, but for now it's good enough.
- Optics/display. Any VR enthusiast will tell you that display optics/FOV/resolution are extremely important for a VR Headset. Just like you want a big, high-resolution TV to play games on for your console (or movies), same for VR. Quest 3 is a step improvement over the Quest 2 for sure. Is it amazing? It's better than most Headsets out there, but I expect all VR headsets to continue to improve on displays. For now, Quest 3 gets the job done.
- Size. I can tell that the Quest 3 is smaller and better balanced (but not really lighter than Quest 2). I had a tough time taking my Quest 2 out of the house for trips and such. With the rings off the controller and slightly smaller headset, it travels better (but still bulky) than Quest 2. The controller size is a great improvement overall as well and helps with storage and travel.
For other things like audio, battery life, comfort, compute, etc.. Quest 3 seems comparable to Quest 2. I have seen folks say that Quest 3 battery life is shorter than Quest 2, but I have not experienced a big difference. Also I have seen some comments on the accessories and chargers used on Quest 2 not being compatible with Quest 3. I bought all new accessories for my Quest 3 since my son now has my Quest 2, so I did not have this issue. I will say that controller hand straps are pretty amazing, and I highly recommend them. I have also seen some comments on overall quality issues (like dead pixels, SW, etc), but for me I have had no real issues. SW/OS seems "glitchy" at times. It does weird things like drains my battery if I don't use my Headset for several days or has issues with switching to hand input mode from controller input mode when I don't expect, but otherwise it's OK.
Now the not so good thing... VR in general is really early in development. There is really no "got to have it" story/application with VR. It's really still just a light gaming platform though there are some cool non-gaming applications like VR YouTube, Prime Video, Wander, etc... In general, all VR companies need to solve this problem long term to get VR in every home if VR is going to survive. Even if VR could replace some other electronic in my house (like my iPad) that would be a big improvement. Right now, if I had to cut my spending on Devices, VR is on the cut list (though I really like VR, it's still not as useful as other electronic devices).
One final note, in looking at Apple's VR future offering, I don't see that device as a Quest line competitor. No real games that I can tell. No controllers for gaming anyway. Seems like Pass-through and "productivity" focused though I don't know what productive things I would use it. The cost difference is huge as well. I am interested in seeing where Apple will go with their product, but I feel like they are trying to something different from Quest.
author: Alan Garner

title: Granmary
text: My grandson love playing Ocular games
author: Mary F Montgomery

title: BEST VR In This Price Category
text: The media could not be loaded. Around the $500-650 price category, this VR headset is the most bang-for-your-buck you’ll ever find for what you get in this package. Everything is so CLEAR and SHARP. Not even mentioning the pancake lenses that have infinite sweet spot and edge-to-edge clarity, zero god-rays, but the Quest 3 has almost as many pixels in ONE eye as the entire Valve Index’s combined resolution. Talk about immersive. Comparatively speaking, if you are also thinking about getting the PSVR2 instead ($549), don’t. Get this. I find my experience with this headset LEAGUES better than anything else I’ve tried, and I’ve tried them all. The graphical capabilities of this headset are mind blowing. At least in the games that are actually updated to take advantage of the Quest 3’s hardware, you forget that it’s all being run inside the headset. This is the closest you’ll ever get to PC quality. To me, this headset after adjustment fits just right, and is way more comfortable than the previous Quest, despite being practically the same weight. Maybe it depends on your face shape, but this headset fits like a glove for me. The only way to top this headset is by spending 2x or 3x times as much money for another VR setup. And for this reason, this is a 5 star product for me. ⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️

author: Leah sanders

title: Incredible device but some advice…
text:
Motion sickness was the real deal for me and as much as I liked the Quest 3 …. I couldn't do it.
My advice…. Absolutely spend the money to get a BOBOvr M3 head strap and battery pack. Or something similar. Comfort is the upmost key to really enjoying VR. Don’t skimp on the headstrap and any accessories that will make your sessions comfortable and fun. This is no joke.
Look into better padding that sits on your face. A matter of sweating and getting itchy to something soft and breathable. Trust me this is a game changer as well.
Fork out the money if you have it to upgrade the stock parts. It will change your experience dramatically.
No matter what I did I couldn’t get over the motion sickness and feeling like I was drugged most the night after my play sessions. Oh well.
author: RedmondIvy

title: Glasses or Zenni Lenses?
text:
This review is for folks who wear glasses and wonder how well the Quest 3 works with them, or if they will need the Zenni lenses. First, they work with my glasses fine, but the Zenni lenses work very well, too. Are they better than using the Quest 3 with glasses? Read on!
I got the Zenni's even though the Quest 3 fit over my glasses fine, just to have the option and for comparison. They arrived fairly quickly, well packaged and the prescription was spot on. I've used them for the past few weeks without any issues. I did have to re-adjust the fit of the Quest 3 to be looking through the lenses at the best angle, distance and eye width. It's like adjusting a new pair of glasses to your face. Once fit properly, it was smooth sailing. If you wear glasses, and spending $50 doesn't bother you, I would definitely get them to see if they work better or more conveniently than over glasses.
Now, are they better than glasses? The Quest 3 fit over my glasses fine, which was a big change from the Quest 2 which fit terribly and lenses were a necessity. I didn't even need to adjust the Quest 3 outward to fit my glasses, so the FOV was fine. The differences in use were somewhat subtle. (1) Since the glasses were on my face, the fit tolerance of the Quest 3 was broader. It could sit a little higher, lower, or at a slight angle to my face and I still saw fine. The pupil distance didn't seem to matter as much for me - anything from 60-63 worked fine. With the Zenni lenses, the Quest is like a pair of glasses - the exact fit matters and I had to dial in the fit on the Quest and the inter-pupil distance exactly for a clear view and minimal eye fatigue. (2) FOV is subtly different. The Zenni lenses effectively sit a bit further from my face than a pair of glasses, which seems to slightly shrink the image the eye sees. Not enough that I cared, but it noticeable if you swap back and forth. The effect for you will depend on your own glasses fit vs the Zenni's. (3) For short sessions, or any time you are taking the Quest 3 on and off often, glasses are more convenient since you don't have to find and put them back on your face. Obviously, if you are sharing the Quest 3, glasses are easier, as well.
Bottom line: If you have any issues with using the Quest 3 with your glasses, get the Zenni's. If they work fine with your glasses, and there is a chance that it will, it might be a toss up, but I find it is a nice option and the lenses have pretty much stayed on my Quest 3 permanently.

text: I bought this not to play games per say. I purchased it to explore the world. I'm a senior citizen and would love to travel the world. And I will but not everywhere I wish to explore. And we have money to spend! I also love the workout apps or games that work up a sweat.

author: Gaurav Kumar

title: Best bang for the buck.. Incredible
text:
For VR pc Sim gaming? Be ready to spend some time and $$$ to get this right.
First off: you need to run Steam beta vr and steam beta. It doesn't work on regular versions.
Secondly you MUST use the LINK cable AND the pc MUST be connected via ethernet. NO WIFI!
Third: If you don't have at least an RTX4060 then don't bother.. It will just cause depression while everyone on the internet tells you it should work and it still doesn't I swear people Gaslight about this🤣🤣
After that!? IT'S AMAZING!!!
So I would say buy this instead of any of the other units.. Use the difference between the $600 for this unit and the $1,000 for the others to buy a very good long 20ft + Link cable, a very long Ethernet cable for your main pc, and a GTX 4060 graphics card.
It's like buying a high end vr setup and getting the rtx4060 for free!
author: Blaqlabs LLC

title: Just the most awesome purchase ever!!!
text:
So, I'm homebound most days (disabled with progressive lupus and rheumatoid arthritis), sometimes bedridden, and I'm so boooored! I decided to purchase this to help me get more involved with physical therapy and meditation and such, but holy crap this thing is so much fun!!!
Yesterday, I rode a bunch of rollercoasters (made me puke irl), took a "walk" around my childhood stomping grounds, meditated in Patagonia (Google Maps) and created my own Universe and did guided meditations. There are *so* many apps you can buy! There's absolutely a *lot* for everyone! It's a blast!
It easily creates boundaries in your room and it's so easy to switch between pure virtual reality and pass through, which is great for me because my cats keep wondering what I'm screaming about and try to help me and I don't want to step on my babies. I love every game I've played, and again, there is so much to choose from. I'm definitely encouraged to do more exercise, granted I've overdone it and hurt worse, but I'll heal in a day or two. Plus, you can play from a couch or bed, too. It's just so much fun!!! I love shooting aliens and zombies breaking into my house!
My father-in-law played this the other night and freaked out on a rollercoaster. Hilarious and definite TikTok material! He's in love with Meta Quest 3 and called to tell me he bought his own because it's so much fun!
Definitely the best purchase of the year! The graphics are just so awesome and I think it's comfortable to wear. I don't see any outside light getting through. The chargeonly lasts about 2 hours, but really, you need a break after that. That's my only complaint. Charges fast, though!
author: Shaye Kato

title: So responsive, improved graphics!
text: Obsessed with the Quest 3. It's a major upgrade from Quest 2. The headset detects the boundary by itself and very precicely. The augmented (passthrough) mode is not perfectly clear but a massive improvement from the grayscale blurry vision we had with Quest 2. The apps look so much clearer and graphics improvement is definitely noticeable. The apps also load quicker. Battery drain seems slightly improved from Quest 2. Still drains relatively quick for my taste but considering the graphics heavy apps I use, it's understandable. Love the ability to use my hands along with the controllers.

text:
This VR is AMAZING 😳. The pass through is superb! I just need a wire to charge it while I play. I’m so happy I got this instead of a new 3D printer. Amazing hands down. My first VR experience.
Update!
I’m still loving this VR heat set. I don’t need a charging cord to play longer. I bought an aftermarket battery pack headset which is fantastic! This isn’t just for gaming! You can explore the internet. You can workout in it with games such as Supernatural app. You can watch IMAX videos and geographies which I really love to do. You can watch 3D MOVIES with this headset in an app call BIGSCREEN. You can video call your friends in VR. Don’t listen to the negative critics.

title: Best VR headset I’ve ever owned
text: It quickly became apparent after a few hours of use, that this was the best VR headset I’ve owned. And I’ve owned 7 in total including most recently the PSVR 2 & Reverb G2. The star of the show are the new pancake lenses, they are INCREDIBLE. Until now, constantly adjusting the headset to find the sweet spot, was always part of the experience. These lenses provide edge to edge clarity and is a true game changer. The speakers were also impressive and I’ve not felt the need to use my own. I can easily recommend this headset to anyone.

author: Nick

title: Huge Lens Upgrade from Quest 2
text:
The resolution is a noticeable 30% bump from the Quest 2, but the real visual upgrade is the pancake lens. On the Q2, the sweet spot is a very small area directly in front, and there's a lot of blurry distortion the further from the center. Quest 3 you'll have sharpness for most of your field of vision. There is still a bit of a halo effect, but it's wider and most noticeable when staring at something bright in a dark area.
The Quest 2 also had only 3 IPD options to account for varying amount of space between eyes. The Quest 3 has a full range of IPD adjustment since the two screens can move independently.
The only downsides are battery life (now as low as 1.2hr in my experience), and comfort (the standard rubber facial interface of the Q2 was more comfortable). But both of these issues are usually the first things that get mudded anyways, with battery straps and alternate interfaces.

author: jose

title: For me good enough to work full time through VR desktop (long review)
text:
I have always dreamed of ditching my monitors and having just a VR desktop. I could work much more relaxed than hunched over a monitor, with my shoulder muscles cramping after a day of work. I already use my laptop to work anywhere in the house, but that freedom limits me to a single screen. Note that I am a software developer by profession, and I typically spend 10 hours a day coding.
I was actually very skeptical that I could do real work in text editors with this thing. I decided to give it a try anyway. I am very glad I did, and here's my take after 2 full days of use.
First, my setup: I use the Immersed app over wifi with my Windows 11 laptop. I work tethered with a 10 foot usb cord for power only, with a 30 watt aftermarket charger, which can charge the headset while still keeping it powered up indefinitely. I started with the 3 monitors free Immersed gives you, but cut down to 2 to feel less cramped by displays. My coding is done in Eclipse and VScode, and the text is very legible. I was worried about the field of view, but it is absolutely not an issue. The pass through portal in Immersed is great to allow you to see your real desktop, with your keyboard and coffee, while the rest of your environment is some chalet in the alps, or a space station, or whatever. You can also work within your real environment, but with virtual screens floating in front of you, if you want (see my comments about passthrough further on).
The first day was fine except after the first 8 hours my face started hurting because of the pressure needed to keep the headset in place. I powered through the discomfort and after the 10th hour it wasn't bad anymore. Today I added a counter balance velcroed to the back strap and it has been MUCH better. I can loosen the strap so it doesn't press the headset against my face, but it stays perfectly in place due to the added rear counterbalance. I do not feel the that extra weight, only the benefit of the lighter fit on my face.
How about my eyes ? You may not believe it, but after I spent many hours with the headset, my eyes are actually relaxed much more than when using a monitor. I've been far sighted (had Lasik many years ago) and use reading glasses for normal work, but do not need glasses with this headset. Make sure you tweak the interpupilary distance adjustment as well as you can for yourself to avoid eye strain. I believe that I may have a slight difference in strength between my eyes that strains them with regular monitor use, but with the Quest 3 and that adjustment, my eyes feel very fresh even after 10 hours of use.. Incredible, I know. Perhaps if you have perfect normal vision, you may have issues with using the headset, but for me it's improving my experience. On top of allowing me to stay relaxed in my easy chair when I work. It's only my second full day, and if my experience with comfort changes, I'll update this review.
Some things to watch for. I've had to reset it maybe 3 times these past two days, with a combined 22 hours of use. One time because I started getting some strange glitchiness, like streaks of gray fuzzy lines crossing my field of view all over the place, or voice command errors popping up continuously when I didn't even use it and had turned voice control off. The restarts cleared things up. One annoying thing is that though the computer speakers can play through the headset, you cannot use the headset microphone through the computer, for example in meetings or chats, so I have to keep the laptop very nearby so its microphone can pick me up. I'm sure that will be solved in a future update.
The passthrough cameras work, you can see the outside world enough to do what you need to do, but not very clear by any means, especially if you're not in a well lit area. This is super minor issue for me, since the virtual monitors is all I really care about, and they are quite crisp.
My big fear is that the headset was not meant for such intensive daily use and that it may die out on me. I guess we'll see if the Meta warranty is any good if that ever happens. I'm debating purchasing the supplemental 2 year warranty that is available to get within 60 days of purchasing the headset.
One last note, if you want to try a very cool experience to get a taste of VR, I highly recommend the free Oculus First Contact app in the store. A fun but very well done (imho) demo of what you can do in VR - great for all ages.
